VIII.iv.9.A.1.a
.
Definition:  Special Operations
Special Operations
are small-scale covert or overt military operations of an unorthodox and frequently high-risk nature, to include training, undertaken to achieve significant political or military objectives in support of foreign policy.
Special Operations units are
typically composed of relatively small groups of highly-trained, armed personnel, and
often transported by helicopter, small boats, or submarines, or parachute from aircraft for stealthy infiltration.
Examples
:
U.S. Army’s Special Forces, commonly called the “Green Berets.”
U.S. Navy Sea, Air, and Land Teams (SEALs).
U.S. Air Force Special Tactics Squadrons.
U.S. Marine Corps Raiders.
U.S. Army Rangers.
160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment.
Note
:  Some Special Operations, such as counter-terrorism actions, may be carried out domestically under certain circumstances.
title: M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, Chapter 9, Section A - Claims Based on Participation in Special Operations Incidents
citation: Part VIII, Subpart iv, Chapter 9, Section A
